title: Man who suffered stroke aged 19 able to walk and talk again after incredible recovery
text:

A teenage stroke victim has spoken about his struggle to walk and talk again as he tried to rebuild his life.

Niall Woods was just 19 when he suffered a stroke that left him in a coma for six months.

Ten years on and the 29-year-old from South Belfast, regularly swims and goes to the gym as part of his recovery process, Belfast Live reports.

Niall has spoken as The Stroke Association published research which found that almost nine in ten (88%) stroke survivors are “afraid they won’t get better” while four out of five (80%) fear they will get sent to a care home.

(Image: Irish Daily Mirror)

He said: “When I had my stroke people thought I wouldn’t walk again.

"I’d gone from being an active guy to feeling like my life had changed forever.

"Since then I’ve worked hard on my recovery by getting involved in lots of activities such as going to the gym and swimming.

“When I left hospital the most important thing to me was to get back on my feet and walking again. I remember back at the start wanting to drive so badly as I saw it as freedom and so I’m really proud that I passed my driving test seven years ago.

"It made a massive difference to my life. I’m now able to get out independently and for me, that’s a big deal."

The Stroke Association research also found that 89% of survivors “live in fear of having another stroke”, while 79% are “afraid for their recovery”.

The charity’s research (which they say comes from a survey of more than 1,000 stroke survivors) also found one in five (20%) stroke survivors keep their fears to themselves.

Niall said: “I love exercising. I do it because it helps me and every day I exercise, makes me stronger and that little bit better.

"Swimming is very important to me now, not only because it helps me with my physical recovery from stroke but also, it’s a great way for me to unwind and clear my head when things get on top of me.

"I’m proud that I’m able to drive and swim and that I can walk again but to me, it isn’t good enough yet and there’s still work to be done.

"The team from the Stroke Association have helped me to focus on my goals and rebuilding my life after stroke."

The study also discovered only 18% of stroke survivors were “confident that they would get enough support to make a good recovery”; 87% of stroke survivors “feared losing their independence” and that 81% “were afraid they wouldn’t be able to look after their children or parents”.

Juliet Bouverie, Chief Executive of the Stroke Association, said: “These stats are truly shocking. I am heartbroken to hear that stroke survivors felt they couldn’t speak to those closest to them about their biggest worries and fears.

"When you live in isolation, too afraid to leave the house and are unable to ask for help, your motivation can disappear, and can leave you in a very bad place emotionally – feeling like a prisoner in your own home.

“It takes a team to rebuild lives after stroke. When stroke strikes, part of your brain shuts down, and so does a part of you. Recovery is tough, but with the right specialist support, the brain can adapt after stroke.

"I’ve heard countless stories, and know countless people who, after many years continue to make remarkable recoveries.

“The first step to eliminating fear is to ask for help and support.

"If you are a stroke survivor, this could mean speaking to your doctor or social worker to get some answers. If you know a stroke survivor, reach out, ask them how they’re feeling. No one should have to live their life in constant fear.”

For more information and advice from the Stroke Association or call their helpline on 0303 3033 100.
